description: A comprehensive monitoring solution for XRPL (Ripple) validator nodes. Provides real-time metrics, performance tracking, and alerting through Grafana and Prometheus with a custom Python monitoring service.

options.content: üõ°Ô∏è Monitor Health:

panels.description:
Overall health of the monitoring system state management. Checks if state backups are functioning and critical metrics are being persisted. 0=Failed,
  0.5=Degraded, 1=OK.

WebSocket connection health to rippled. Monitors heartbeat (ping every 30s), connection status, and auto-reconnection. If unhealthy, automatic
  reconnection will attempt to restore connection.

HTTP JSON-RPC connection health to rippled. Monitors uptime exporter scraping rippled's HTTP endpoint every 5 seconds. Detects failures within 3-6
  seconds.

Python collector process health. Monitors if the main monitoring application (main.py) is running and emitting metrics every 30 seconds. Container crash
   or stop detected immediately.

Data collection status based on rippled state.

‚Ä¢ Streaming: rippled is fully synced and producing data
‚Ä¢ Syncing: rippled is starting up and syncing with the network
‚Ä¢ No Stream: rippled is not responding or collector is down
VictoriaMetrics database health. Verifies database can respond to queries and store metrics. If down, all dashboard panels will show 'No data'.
Resource pressure via PSI
panels.title: Pressure

panels.description: Overall CPU busy percentage (averaged across all cores)
panels.title: CPU Busy

panels.description: System load  over all CPU cores together
panels.title: Sys Load

panels.description: Real RAM usage excluding cache and reclaimable memory
panels.title: RAM Used

panels.description: Percentage of swap space currently used by the system
panels.title: SWAP Used

panels.description: Used Root FS
panels.title: Root FS Used

panels.description:
Time since your validator (rippled) last started. Longer uptimes indicate stability. Restarts reset this counter. Frequent restarts may indicate crashes or manual intervention.

No thresholds - longer is generally better.
panels.title: Uptime

panels.description:
Current operational state of your XRPL validator. Indicates sync status and consensus participation level.

States (best to worst):
- Green: proposing (actively validating), full (synced)
- Yellow: validating, tracking, syncing, connected
- Red: disconnected, offline
panels.title: State

panels.description:
Latest validated ledger sequence number on the XRPL network. New ledgers close approximately every 3-4 seconds. This number should continuously increase.

No thresholds - always increasing.
panels.title: Current Ledger

panels.description:
Your rippled software version. Keep updated for security and network compatibility. Check xrpl.org for latest releases and upgrade advisories.

No thresholds - check for updates regularly.
panels.title: Release Version

panels.description:
Your validator's public key (nHU...). This uniquely identifies your validator on the network. Used in validator lists and for tracking your validator's reputation.

No thresholds - informational.
panels.title: Pubkey

panels.description:
Current XRPL network fee settings. Base Fee is the minimum transaction cost. Reserve Base is the minimum XRP an account must hold. Reserve Increment is XRP reserved per owned object.

No thresholds - network-determined values.
panels.title: XRP Fees

panels.description:
Total validations sent by this validator since rippled last started. Resets on rippled restart but survives monitor restarts. Should steadily increase at ~15-18 per minute.

No thresholds - should always increase.
panels.title: Validations Sent

panels.description:
Network-wide ledger close rate in ledgers per minute. Typically 15-18/min (one ledger every 3-4 seconds). Compare with your Validation Rate to monitor participation.

Thresholds:
- Green: ‚â•9/min
- Yellow: 8/min
- Red: <8/min
panels.title: Ledgers Per Minute

panels.description:
Validation messages YOUR validator publishes per minute. Should track closely with Ledgers Per Minute. Lower values indicate your validator is missing validations.

Thresholds:
- Green: ‚â•12/min
- Yellow: 10-11/min
- Red: <10/min
panels.title: Validation Rate

panels.description:
Seconds since the last validated ledger closed. Should reset to 0 every 3-4 seconds as new ledgers close. High values indicate your validator may be falling behind the network.

Thresholds:
- Green: ‚â§10 seconds
- Yellow: 10-30 seconds
- Red: >30 seconds
panels.title: Ledger Age

panels.description:
Server load multiplier affecting transaction fees. 1.0 is normal baseline. High values indicate the server is under stress and may reject transactions or increase fees.

Thresholds:
- Green: <100 (1.0x multiplier)
- Yellow: 100-499 (1-5x multiplier)
- Red: ‚â•500 (5x+ multiplier)
panels.title: Load Factor

panels.description:
Rate of peer disconnections per second. Some churn is normal as peers rotate. Sustained high rates indicate network instability, firewall issues, or connectivity problems.

Thresholds:
- Green: <0.1/sec
- Red: ‚â•0.1/sec
panels.title: Peer Disconnects

panels.description:
Ledger DB size as percentage of root filesystem. Based on actual disk capacity for universal thresholds.

Thresholds:
- Green: <60%
- Yellow: 60-80%
- Red: >80%
panels.title: Ledger DB

panels.description:
NuDB ledger database size as percentage of root filesystem. Based on actual disk capacity for universal thresholds.

Thresholds:
- Green: <60%
- Yellow: 60-80%
- Red: >80%
panels.title: Ledger NuDB

panels.description:
Percentage of ledgers where your validator agreed with network consensus in the last hour. More sensitive to recent issues than the 24h metric.

Thresholds:
- Green: ‚â•98%
- Yellow: 95-97%
- Red: <95%
panels.title: Agreements % (1h)

panels.description:
Total count of ledger validations where your validator agreed with network consensus in the last hour. Typically ~900-1200 per hour. Compare with Missed (1h) to identify issues.

No thresholds - informational metric.
panels.title: Agreements (1h)

panels.description:
Ledgers your validator should have validated but missed in the last hour. Ideally 0. Even 1-2 missed validations warrant investigation if it's a pattern. High counts indicate connectivity, sync, or performance issues.

Thresholds: Green=0, Yellow=1-5, Red=>5
panels.title: Missed (1h)

panels.description:
Total number of peer rippled servers connected to your validator. Healthy validators typically maintain 21+ peers for reliable network participation.

Thresholds:
- Green: ‚â•21 peers
- Yellow: 19-20 peers
- Red: <19 peers
panels.title: Total Peers

panels.description:
Peers your validator actively connected TO. Your validator initiates and maintains these outbound connections. Important for network resilience.

Thresholds:
- Green: ‚â•6 peers
- Yellow: 5 peers
- Red: <5 peers
panels.title: Outbound Peers

panels.description:
Peers that connected TO your validator. Higher inbound counts indicate your validator is well-connected and discoverable on the network.

Thresholds:
- Green: ‚â•6 peers
- Yellow: 5 peers
- Red: <5 peers
panels.title: Inbound Peers

panels.description:
Peers on a different ledger chain (wrong network fork). Usually 0-3 during normal operation. High counts may indicate a network split, misconfigured peers, or testnet connections.

Thresholds:
- Green: <10 peers
- Yellow: 10-19 peers
- Red: ‚â•20 peers
panels.title: Insane Peers

panels.description:
Network latency to connected peers (P90 - 90th percentile). More reliable than average as it filters out the slowest 10% outliers. Lower latency improves consensus participation.

Thresholds:
- Green: <400ms
- Yellow: 400-500ms
- Red: >500ms
panels.title: Peer Latency

panels.description:
Percentage of ledgers where your validator agreed with network consensus in the last 24 hours. The key metric for overall validator health and reliability.

Thresholds:
- Green: ‚â•99%
- Yellow: 95-98%
- Red: <95%
panels.title: Agreements % (24h)

panels.description:
Total count of ledgers your validator successfully validated and agreed with network consensus in the last 24 hours. Typically ~21,600-25,920 per day (15-18 ledgers/min). Compare with Missed (24h) for context.

No thresholds - informational metric.
panels.title: Agreements (24h)

panels.description:
Ledgers your validator should have validated but missed in the last 24 hours. Ideally near 0. Values >50 indicate persistent connectivity, sync, or performance issues requiring investigation.

Thresholds: Green=0-10, Yellow=11-50, Red=>50
panels.title: Missed (24h)

panels.description:
Network transactions processed per second (TPS). Indicates XRPL network activity level. Typical range is 10-40 TPS. Very high rates may stress validator resources.

Thresholds:
- Green: <200 TPS
- Yellow: 200-500 TPS
- Red: >500 TPS
panels.title: Transaction Rate

panels.description:
Number of validators that proposed in the last consensus round. Should be close to or higher than quorum for healthy consensus. Low values may indicate network-wide issues.

Thresholds:
- Green: ‚â•11 proposers
- Yellow: 10 proposers
- Red: <10 proposers
panels.title: Proposers

panels.description:
Number of UNL validators required to reach consensus (80% of trusted validators). Determined by your validator list configuration. Default Ripple UNL typically requires 28-29.

Thresholds:
- Green: 20-40 (healthy range)
- Yellow: 19 (low end)
- Red: <19 or >40 (abnormal)
panels.title: Quorum

panels.description:
Time in seconds for the last ledger to reach network consensus. Indicates how efficiently the network is agreeing on transactions. Longer times may signal network congestion or validator issues.

Thresholds:
- Green: <6 seconds
- Yellow: 6-7 seconds
- Red: >7 seconds
panels.title: Consensus

panels.description:
Days until Validator List (UNL) expires. List auto-updates from publishers. If critically low, check network connectivity to vl.ripple.com and vl.xrplf.org.

Thresholds:
- Green: ‚â•30 days
- Yellow: 14-29 days
- Red: <14 days
panels.title: UNL Expiry

panels.description:
CPU usage of the rippled validator process over time. Values can exceed 100% on multi-core systems (e.g., 200% = 2 full cores). Monitor for sustained high usage indicating performance issues.

Typical ranges:
- Normal: 5-30%
- High activity: 30-80%
- Investigate: >100% sustained
panels.title: Validator CPU Load

panels.description:
TCP network traffic rate for your validator in segments per second. Shows both inbound and outbound traffic patterns. Spikes correlate with network activity and peer synchronization.

Typical ranges:
- Idle: 100-500 seg/s
- Normal: 500-2000 seg/s
- High activity: 2000+ seg/s
panels.title: Network TCP In / Out

panels.description:
Validation activity rates over time. Compare your validator's output against network totals to ensure healthy participation.

Lines explained:
- Green: Total network validations (~3000/min from all validators)
- Yellow: YOUR validator's validations (~15-20/min)

Your line should track steadily; drops indicate missed validations.
panels.title: Activity Rates

panels.description:
Historical trend of server load factor over time. Use to identify performance patterns, degradation trends, and capacity planning needs.

Typical ranges:
- Normal: ~1.0 (baseline)
- Elevated: 1.0-2.0 (monitor)
- High: 2.0-5.0 (investigate)
- Critical: >5.0 (action needed)

targets.legendFormat: Historical view of server load factor over time

panels.title: Load Factor Over Time

panels.description:
XRPL network transaction throughput over time. Use to correlate validator performance with network load and identify activity patterns.

Typical ranges:
- Low activity: 5-15 TPS
- Normal: 15-40 TPS
- High activity: 40-100 TPS
- Spike: >100 TPS (network events)

targets.legendFormat: Network transaction throughput over time in TPS

panels.title: Transaction Rate

panels.description:
Historical trend of your validator's agreement with network consensus. Use to identify patterns in validation problems and verify fixes over time.

Target ranges:
- Excellent: ‚â•99%
- Good: 95-99%
- Concerning: 90-95%
- Critical: <90% (investigate immediately)

targets.legendFormat: Historical validation agreement percentage over time

panels.title: Agreement % Trend

panels.description:
Disk I/O latency over time. Critical for validator performance as ledger operations depend on fast disk access. Increasing trends may indicate disk degradation or saturation.

Typical ranges:
- NVMe/SSD excellent: <5ms
- SSD good: 5-15ms
- Acceptable: 15-30ms
- Investigate: >30ms

targets.legendFormat: Disk I/O response time over time in milliseconds

panels.title: IO Latency

panels.description:
Historical trend of YOUR validator's validation rate over time. Use to identify patterns in validation performance and correlate with other metrics.

Target ranges:
- Healthy: 12-18/min (tracks ledger close rate)
- Low: 10-12/min (some missed)
- Critical: <10/min (investigate)

targets.legendFormat: Percentage of expected validations actually performed over time

panels.title: Validation Rate

panels.description:
Time required for network to reach consensus on each ledger. Use to diagnose consensus delays and network participation problems over time.

Typical ranges:
- Fast: 2-3 seconds
- Normal: 3-4 seconds
- Slow: 4-6 seconds
- Investigate: >6 seconds consistently

targets.legendFormat: Time required to reach consensus on each ledger in seconds

panels.title: Consensus Converge Time

panels.description:
Historical trend of peer connections. Use to identify connectivity patterns, network stability, and reachability issues over time.

Typical ranges:
- Healthy: 21-50 peers (stable)
- Acceptable: 15-21 peers
- Low: 10-15 peers (monitor)
- Critical: <10 peers (investigate)

targets.legendFormat: Total connected peer servers over time

panels.title: Peer Count Over Time

panels.description: CPU time spent busy vs idle, split by activity type
panels.title: CPU Basic

panels.description: RAM and swap usage overview, including caches
panels.title: Memory Basic

panels.description: Per-interface network traffic (receive and transmit) in bits per second
panels.title: Network Traffic Basic

panels.description: Percentage of filesystem space used for each mounted device

targets.expr: ((node_filesystem_size_bytes{instance="$node", job="$job", device!~"rootfs"} - node_filesystem_avail_bytes{instance="$node", job="$job", device!~"rootfs"}) / node_filesystem_size_bytes{instance="$node", job="$job", device!~"rootfs"}) * 100

panels.title: Disk Space Used Basic

panels.description: CPU time usage split by state, normalized across all CPU cores

matcher.options: Idle - Waiting for something to happen
Iowait - Waiting for I/O to complete
Nice - Niced processes executing in user mode
Steal - Time spent in other operating systems when running in a virtualized environment
System - Processes executing in kernel mode
User - Normal processes executing in user mode

targets.legendFormat: System - Processes executing in kernel mode
User - Normal processes executing in user mode
Nice - Niced processes executing in user mode
Iowait - Waiting for I/O to complete
Steal - Time spent in other operating systems when running in a virtualized environment
Idle - Waiting for something to happen

targets.expr: sum by(instance) (irate(node_cpu_guest_seconds_total{instance="$node",job="$job"}[$__rate_interval])) / on(instance) group_left sum by (instance)((irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{instance="$node",job="$job"}[$__rate_interval]))) > 0

panels.title: CPU

panels.description: Breakdown of physical memory and swap usage. Hardware-detected memory errors are also displayed

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

targets.legendFormat: Apps - Memory used by user-space applications
PageTables - Memory used to map between virtual and physical memory addresses
SwapCache - Memory that keeps track of pages that have been fetched from swap but not yet been modified
Slab - Memory used by the kernel to cache data structures for its own use (caches like inode, dentry, etc)
Cache - Parked file data (file content) cache
Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

panels.title: Memory

panels.description: Incoming and outgoing network traffic per interface
panels.title: Network Traffic

panels.description: Network interface utilization as a percentage of its maximum capacity
panels.title: Network Saturation

panels.description: Disk I/O operations per second for each device
panels.title: Disk IOps

panels.description: Disk I/O throughput per device
panels.title: Disk Throughput

panels.description: Amount of available disk space per mounted filesystem, excluding rootfs. Based on block availability to non-root users
panels.title: Filesystem Space Available

panels.description: Disk usage (used = total - available) per mountpoint
panels.title: Filesystem Used

panels.description: Percentage of time the disk was actively processing I/O operations
panels.title: Disk I/O Utilization

panels.description:
How often tasks experience CPU, memory, or I/O delays. ‚ÄúSome‚Äù indicates partial slowdown; ‚ÄúFull‚Äù indicates all tasks are stalled. Based on Linux PSI metrics:
https://docs.kernel.org/accounting/psi.html
panels.title: Pressure Stall Information

panels.description: Displays committed memory usage versus the system's commit limit. Exceeding the limit is allowed under Linux overcommit policies but may increase OOM risks under high load

targets.legendFormat: Committed_AS ‚Äì Memory promised to processes (not necessarily used)

panels.title: Memory Committed

panels.description: Memory currently dirty (modified but not yet written to disk), being actively written back, or held by writeback buffers. High dirty or writeback memory may indicate disk I/O pressure or delayed flushing

targets.legendFormat: Writeback ‚Äì Memory currently being flushed to disk
Dirty ‚Äì Memory marked dirty (pending write to disk)
NFS Unstable ‚Äì Pages sent to NFS server, awaiting storage commit

panels.title: Memory Writeback and Dirty

panels.description: Kernel slab memory usage, separated into reclaimable and non-reclaimable categories. Reclaimable memory can be freed under memory pressure (e.g., caches), while unreclaimable memory is locked by the kernel for core functions

targets.legendFormat: SReclaimable ‚Äì Potentially reclaimable slab memory (e.g., inode cache)

panels.title: Memory Slab

panels.description: Memory used for mapped files (such as libraries) and shared memory (shmem and tmpfs), including variants backed by huge pages

targets.legendFormat: Mapped ‚Äì Memory mapped from files (e.g., libraries, mmap)
Shmem ‚Äì Shared memory used by processes and tmpfs
ShmemHugePages ‚Äì Shared memory (shmem/tmpfs) allocated with HugePages
PMD Mapped ‚Äì Shmem/tmpfs backed by Transparent HugePages (PMD)

panels.title: Memory Shared and Mapped

panels.description: Proportion of memory pages in the kernel's active and inactive LRU lists relative to total RAM. Active pages have been recently used, while inactive pages are less recently accessed but still resident in memory

targets.legendFormat: Inactive ‚Äì Less recently used memory, more likely to be reclaimed
Active ‚Äì Recently used memory, retained unless under pressure

panels.title: Memory LRU Active / Inactive (%)

panels.description: Breakdown of memory pages in the kernel's active and inactive LRU lists, separated by anonymous (heap, tmpfs) and file-backed (caches, mmap) pages.

targets.legendFormat: Inactive_file - File-backed memory on inactive LRU list
Inactive_anon ‚Äì Anonymous memory on inactive LRU (incl. tmpfs & swap cache)
Active_file - File-backed memory on active LRU list
Active_anon ‚Äì Anonymous memory on active LRU (incl. tmpfs & swap cache)

panels.title: Memory LRU Active / Inactive Detail

panels.description: Tracks kernel memory used for CPU-local structures, per-thread stacks, and bounce buffers used for I/O on DMA-limited devices. These areas are typically small but critical for low-level operations

targets.legendFormat: PerCPU ‚Äì Dynamically allocated per-CPU memory (used by kernel modules)
Bounce Memory ‚Äì I/O buffer for DMA-limited devices

panels.title: Memory Kernel / CPU / IO

panels.description: Usage of the kernel's vmalloc area, which provides virtual memory allocations for kernel modules and drivers. Includes total, used, and largest free block sizes

targets.legendFormat: Vmalloc Free Chunk ‚Äì Largest available block in vmalloc area
Vmalloc Total ‚Äì Total size of the vmalloc memory area
Vmalloc Used ‚Äì Portion of vmalloc area currently in use

panels.title: Memory Vmalloc

panels.description: Memory used by anonymous pages (not backed by files), including standard and huge page allocations. Includes heap, stack, and memory-mapped anonymous regions
panels.title: Memory Anonymous

panels.description: Memory that is locked in RAM and cannot be swapped out. Includes both kernel-unevictable memory and user-level memory locked with mlock()

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

panels.title: Memory Unevictable and MLocked

panels.description: How much memory is directly mapped in the kernel using different page sizes (4K, 2M, 1G). Helps monitor large page utilization in the direct map region
panels.title: Memory DirectMap

panels.description: Displays HugePages memory usage in bytes, including allocated, free, reserved, and surplus memory. All values are calculated based on the number of huge pages multiplied by their configured size
panels.title: Memory HugePages

panels.description: Rate of memory pages being read from or written to disk (page-in and page-out operations). High page-out may indicate memory pressure or swapping activity
panels.title: Memory Pages In / Out

panels.description: Rate at which memory pages are being swapped in from or out to disk. High swap-out activity may indicate memory pressure
panels.title: Memory Pages Swap In / Out

panels.description: Rate of memory page faults, split into total, major (disk-backed), and derived minor (non-disk) faults. High major fault rates may indicate memory pressure or insufficient RAM

matcher.options: Pgfault - Page major and minor fault ops

targets.legendFormat: Pgfault - Page major and minor fault ops

panels.title: Memory Page Faults

panels.description: Rate of Out-of-Memory (OOM) kill events. A non-zero value indicates the kernel has terminated one or more processes due to memory exhaustion
panels.title: OOM Killer

panels.description: Tracks the system clock's estimated and maximum error, as well as its offset from the reference clock (e.g., via NTP). Useful for detecting synchronization drift
panels.title: Time Synchronized Drift

panels.description: NTP phase-locked loop (PLL) time constant used by the kernel to control time adjustments. Lower values mean faster correction but less stability
panels.title: Time PLL Adjust

panels.description: Shows whether the system clock is synchronized to a reliable time source, and the current frequency correction ratio applied by the kernel to maintain synchronization
panels.title: Time Synchronized Status

panels.description: Displays the PPS signal's frequency offset and stability (jitter) in hertz. Useful for monitoring high-precision time sources like GPS or atomic clocks
panels.title: PPS Frequency / Stability

panels.description: Tracks PPS signal timing jitter and shift compared to system clock
panels.title: PPS Time Accuracy

panels.description: Rate of PPS synchronization diagnostics including calibration events, jitter violations, errors, and frequency stability exceedances
panels.title: PPS Sync Events

panels.description: Processes currently in runnable or blocked states. Helps identify CPU contention or I/O wait bottlenecks.
panels.title: Processes Status

panels.description: Current number of processes in each state (e.g., running, sleeping, zombie). Requires --collector.processes to be enabled in node_exporter
panels.title: Processes Detailed States

panels.description: Rate of new processes being created on the system (forks/sec).
panels.title: Processes Forks

panels.description: Shows CPU saturation per core, calculated as the proportion of time spent waiting to run relative to total time demanded (running + waiting).
panels.title: CPU Saturation per Core

panels.description: Number of active PIDs on the system and the configured maximum allowed. Useful for detecting PID exhaustion risk. Requires --collector.processes in node_exporter
panels.title: PIDs Number and Limit

panels.description: Number of active threads on the system and the configured thread limit. Useful for monitoring thread pressure. Requires --collector.processes in node_exporter
panels.title: Threads Number and Limit

panels.description: Per-second rate of context switches and hardware interrupts. High values may indicate intense CPU or I/O activity
panels.title: Context Switches / Interrupts

panels.description: System load average over 1, 5, and 15 minutes. Reflects the number of active or waiting processes. Values above CPU core count may indicate overload
panels.title: System Load

panels.description: Real-time CPU frequency scaling per core, including average minimum and maximum allowed scaling frequencies
panels.title: CPU Frequency Scaling

panels.description: Rate of scheduling timeslices executed per CPU. Reflects how frequently the scheduler switches tasks on each core
panels.title: CPU Schedule Timeslices

panels.description: Breaks down hardware interrupts by type and device. Useful for diagnosing IRQ load on network, disk, or CPU interfaces. Requires --collector.interrupts to be enabled in node_exporter
panels.title: IRQ Detail

panels.description: Number of bits of entropy currently available to the system's random number generators (e.g., /dev/random). Low values may indicate that random number generation could block or degrade performance of cryptographic operations
panels.title: Entropy

panels.description: Monitors hardware sensor temperatures and critical thresholds as exposed by Linux hwmon. Includes CPU, GPU, and motherboard sensors where available
panels.title: Hardware Temperature Monitor

panels.description: Shows how hard each cooling device (fan/throttle) is working relative to its maximum capacity
panels.title: Cooling Device Utilization

panels.description: Shows the online status of power supplies (e.g., AC, battery). A value of 1-Yes indicates the power supply is active/online
panels.title: Power Supply

panels.description: Displays the current fan speeds (RPM) from hardware sensors via the hwmon interface
panels.title: Hardware Fan Speed

panels.description: Current number of systemd units in each operational state, such as active, failed, inactive, or transitioning
panels.title: Systemd Units State

panels.description: Current number of active connections per systemd socket, as reported by the Node Exporter systemd collector
panels.title: Systemd Sockets Current

panels.description: Rate of accepted connections per second for each systemd socket
panels.title: Systemd Sockets Accepted

panels.description: Rate of systemd socket connection refusals per second, typically due to service unavailability or backlog overflow
panels.title: Systemd Sockets Refused

panels.description: Number of I/O operations completed per second for the device (after merges), including both reads and writes
panels.title: Disk Read/Write IOps

panels.description: Number of bytes read from or written to the device per second
panels.title: Disk Read/Write Data

panels.description: Average time for requests issued to the device to be served. This includes the time spent by the requests in queue and the time spent servicing them.
panels.title: Disk Average Wait Time

panels.description: Average queue length of the requests that were issued to the device
panels.title: Average Queue Size

panels.description: Number of read and write requests merged per second that were queued to the device
panels.title: Disk R/W Merged

panels.description: Percentage of time the disk spent actively processing I/O operations, including general I/O, discards (TRIM), and write cache flushes
panels.title: Time Spent Doing I/Os

panels.description: Per-second rate of discard (TRIM) and flush (write cache) operations. Useful for monitoring low-level disk activity on SSDs and advanced storage
panels.title: Disk Ops Discards / Flush

panels.description: Shows how many disk sectors are discarded (TRIMed) per second. Useful for monitoring SSD behavior and storage efficiency
panels.title: Disk Sectors Discarded Successfully

panels.description: Number of in-progress I/O requests at the time of sampling (active requests in the disk queue)
panels.title: Instantaneous Queue Size

panels.description: Number of file descriptors currently allocated system-wide versus the system limit. Important for detecting descriptor exhaustion risks
panels.title: File Descriptor

panels.description: Number of free file nodes (inodes) available per mounted filesystem. A low count may prevent file creation even if disk space is available
panels.title: File Nodes Free

panels.description: Indicates filesystems mounted in read-only mode or reporting device-level I/O errors.
panels.title: Filesystem in ReadOnly / Error

panels.description: Number of file nodes (inodes) available per mounted filesystem. Reflects maximum file capacity regardless of disk size
panels.title: File Nodes Size

panels.description: Number of network packets received and transmitted per second, by interface.
panels.title: Network Traffic by Packets

panels.description: Rate of packet-level errors for each network interface. Receive errors may indicate physical or driver issues; transmit errors may reflect collisions or hardware faults
panels.title: Network Traffic Errors

panels.description: Rate of dropped packets per network interface. Receive drops can indicate buffer overflow or driver issues; transmit drops may result from outbound congestion or queuing limits
panels.title: Network Traffic Drop

panels.description: Rate of compressed network packets received and transmitted per interface. These are common in low-bandwidth or special interfaces like PPP or SLIP
panels.title: Network Traffic Compressed

panels.description: Rate of incoming multicast packets received per network interface. Multicast is used by protocols such as mDNS, SSDP, and some streaming or cluster services
panels.title: Network Traffic Multicast

panels.description: Rate of received packets that could not be processed due to missing protocol or handler in the kernel. May indicate unsupported traffic or misconfiguration
panels.title: Network Traffic NoHandler

panels.description: Rate of frame errors on received packets, typically caused by physical layer issues such as bad cables, duplex mismatches, or hardware problems
panels.title: Network Traffic Frame

panels.description: Tracks FIFO buffer overrun errors on network interfaces. These occur when incoming or outgoing packets are dropped due to queue or buffer overflows, often indicating congestion or hardware limits
panels.title: Network Traffic Fifo

panels.description: Rate of packet collisions detected during transmission. Mostly relevant on half-duplex or legacy Ethernet networks
panels.title: Network Traffic Collision

panels.description: Rate of carrier errors during transmission. These typically indicate physical layer issues like faulty cabling or duplex mismatches
panels.title: Network Traffic Carrier Errors

panels.description: Number of ARP entries per interface. Useful for detecting excessive ARP traffic or table growth due to scanning or misconfiguration
panels.title: ARP Entries

panels.description: Current and maximum connection tracking entries used by Netfilter (nf_conntrack). High usage approaching the limit may cause packet drops or connection issues
panels.title: NF Conntrack

panels.description: Operational and physical link status of each network interface. Values are Yes for 'up' or link present, and No for 'down' or no carrier."
panels.title: Network Operational Status

panels.description: Maximum speed of each network interface as reported by the operating system. This is a static hardware capability, not current throughput
panels.title: Speed

panels.description: MTU (Maximum Transmission Unit) in bytes for each network interface. Affects packet size and transmission efficiency
panels.title: MTU

panels.description: Tracks TCP socket usage and memory per node
panels.title: Sockstat TCP

panels.description: Number of UDP and UDPLite sockets currently in use
panels.title: Sockstat UDP

panels.description: Total number of sockets currently in use across all protocols (TCP, UDP, UNIX, etc.), as reported by /proc/net/sockstat
panels.title: Sockstat Used

panels.description: Number of FRAG and RAW sockets currently in use. RAW sockets are used for custom protocols or tools like ping; FRAG sockets are used internally for IP packet defragmentation
panels.title: Sockstat FRAG / RAW

panels.description: TCP/UDP socket memory usage in kernel (in pages)
panels.title: TCP/UDP Kernel Buffer Memory Pages

panels.description: Kernel memory used by TCP, UDP, and IP fragmentation buffers
panels.title: Sockstat Memory Size

panels.description: Packets processed and dropped by the softnet network stack per CPU. Drops may indicate CPU saturation or network driver limitations
panels.title: Softnet Packets

panels.description: How often the kernel was unable to process all packets in the softnet queue before time ran out. Frequent squeezes may indicate CPU contention or driver inefficiency
panels.title: Softnet Out of Quota

panels.description: Tracks the number of packets processed or dropped by Receive Packet Steering (RPS), a mechanism to distribute packet processing across CPUs
panels.title: Softnet RPS

panels.description: Rate of octets sent and received at the IP layer, as reported by /proc/net/netstat
panels.title: Netstat IP In / Out Octets

panels.description: Rate of TCP segments sent and received per second, including data and control segments
panels.title: TCP In / Out

panels.description: Rate of UDP datagrams sent and received per second, based on /proc/net/netstat
panels.title: UDP In / Out

panels.description: Number of ICMP messages sent and received per second, including error and control messages
panels.title: ICMP In / Out

panels.description: Tracks various TCP error and congestion-related events, including retransmissions, timeouts, dropped connections, and buffer issues
panels.title: TCP Errors

panels.description: Rate of UDP and UDPLite datagram delivery errors, including missing listeners, buffer overflows, and protocol-specific issues
panels.title: UDP Errors

panels.description: Rate of incoming ICMP messages that contained protocol-specific errors, such as bad checksums or invalid lengths
panels.title: ICMP Errors

panels.description: Rate of TCP SYN cookies sent, validated, and failed. These are used to protect against SYN flood attacks and manage TCP handshake resources under load
panels.title: TCP SynCookie

panels.description: Number of currently established TCP connections and the system's max supported limit. On Linux, MaxConn may return -1 to indicate a dynamic/unlimited configuration
panels.title: TCP Connections

panels.description: Number of UDP packets currently queued in the receive (RX) and transmit (TX) buffers. A growing queue may indicate a bottleneck
panels.title: UDP Queue

panels.description: Rate of TCP connection initiations per second. 'Active' opens are initiated by this host. 'Passive' opens are accepted from incoming connections
panels.title: TCP Direct Transition

panels.description: Number of TCP sockets in key connection states. Requires the --collector.tcpstat flag on node_exporter
panels.title: TCP Stat

panels.description: Duration of each individual collector executed during a Node Exporter scrape. Useful for identifying slow or failing collectors
panels.title: Node Exporter Scrape Time

panels.description: Rate of CPU time used by the process exposing this metric (user + system mode)
panels.title: Exporter Process CPU Usage

panels.description: Tracks the memory usage of the process exposing this metric (e.g., node_exporter), including current virtual memory and maximum virtual memory limit
panels.title: Exporter Processes Memory

panels.description: Number of file descriptors used by the exporter process versus its configured limit
panels.title: Exporter File Descriptor Usage

panels.description: Shows whether each Node Exporter collector scraped successfully (1 = success, 0 = failure), and whether the textfile collector returned an error.
panels.title: Node Exporter Scrape

title: XRPL Validator Dashboard Cyberpunk
